docs.lead_paragraph: Over the objections of the Justice Department, a Federal judge has cleared the way for the merger of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems, hospital officials said tonight. In a lawsuit filed in June, the Justice Department had charged that the merger would violate antitrust laws, lead to higher hospital rates and inhibit the development of competing hospital systems.

headline.main: Overruling Justice Dept., Judge Clears Path for Long Island Hospital Systems' Merger

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Arthur D Spatt, over objections of Justice Dept, clears way for merger of Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems (M)
docs.snippet: Over the objections of the Justice Department, a Federal judge has cleared the way for the merger of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems, hospital officials said tonight.    In a lawsuit filed in June, the Justice...

docs.lead_paragraph: Bailout of Auto Maker Lifts South Korean Market The South Korean Government's decision to take over Kia Motors, a big auto maker in which Ford owns a stake, sent stock prices to their biggest one-day gain and halted a decline in the nation's currency. But economists cautioned that a number of broader problems remained. [Page D7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Pol Pot Defends Record During Rare Interview ''My conscience is clear,'' declared Pol Pot in the first interview he has given since early 1979. Claims that millions had died in Cambodia at the hands of the Khmer Rouge in the 1970's were exaggerated, he said. A12 Weapons Destroyed in Balkans Some 4,220 tanks, jets, helicopters and artillery pieces belonging to the various Balkan nations have been destroyed in the last 16 months, according to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Officials at the organization would not discuss specific numbers, but noted that the demolition has been carried out by Yugoslavia, Croatia, the Bosnian Serbs and the federation of Bosnian Muslims and Croats, in accordance with a treaty those governments signed in June 1996. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: A Presidential advisory commission decided today to recommend a wide range of new rights for patients, including the right to appeal denials of care or coverage by insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. The 34-member panel, which includes top executives of managed-care companies as well as doctors and consumer advocates, said patients should be able to obtain an ''external review'' of decisions that deny payment for services.

headline.main: PANEL OF EXPERTS URGES BROADENING OF PATIENT RIGHTS

docs.abstract: Presidential advisory commission recommends wide range of new rights for patients, including right to appeal denials of care or coverage by insurance companies and health maintenance organizations; 34-member panel, which includes top executives of managed-care companies as well as doctors and consumer advocates, says patients should be able to obtain 'external review' of decisions that deny payment of services; says patients should have option of appealing to independent outside authority, as Medicare beneficiaries do; says health plans, doctors and hospitals should be required to disclose substantial new information that could help patients assess healthcare providers; panel, called Advisory Commission on Consumer Protection and Quality in Health Care Industry, is headed by Health and Human Services Sec Donna E Shalala and Labor Sec Alexis M Herman (M)
docs.snippet: A Presidential advisory commission decided today to recommend a wide range of new rights for patients, including the right to appeal denials of care or coverage by insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.    The 34-member panel,...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Analysts Expect Health Premiums to Rise Sharply'' (front page, Oct. 19):
docs.abstract: Arthur D Ullian letter on Oct 19 article on expected sharp rise in health premiums (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Analysts Expect Health Premiums to Rise Sharply'' (front page, Oct. 19):

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The news that ''Analysts Expect Health Premiums to Rise Sharply'' (front page, Oct. 19) was predictable. Managed care cut costs at the expense of quality services. The backlash has started.

headline.main: Medical Research Saves Money, Too; Doctors Strike Back
